Posts.Content: His gleason was 3+ 4 primary and secondary, so intermediate risk based on histological grade. pre-op PSA was <10, so low-risk based on that, but overall locally advanced intermediate risk with high risk features (extraprostatic extension). Whole prostate Biopsy was negative for perilymphatic invasion, which means microscopically, lymphatics were not infiltrated (most common route of metastasis). Now if a cancer cell fell off from the EPE into the pelvic bed (during trans-rectal biopsy or actual surgery), God knows...
Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: My first post here. My dad (age 58 at the time of surgery) got diagnosed with T2b prostate cancer on needle biopsy in Oct 2014 with PSA of 6.00. Pre-op CT abdo/pelvis = negative for metastasis Pre-op Bone scan twice = negative for bony metastasis He underwent open radical prostatectomy with sentinel lymph node removal urgently in Jan 2015. No adjuvant radiation as his pathology looked relatively encouraging. On prostate biopsy, his cancer was upgraded to T3a with extraprostatic invasion in right lobe with low tumor volume <10%, negative surgical margins, negative seminal vesicle involvement, negative bladder neck involvement, 1 right pelvic lymph node negative for malignancy, 3 left pelvic lymph node negative for malignancy. His post-op PSAs were: April 2015 PSA = 0.003 August 2015 PSA = 0.005 Oct 2015 PSA = 0.007 Jan 2016 PSA = 0.16 (done in middle east at a different lab from his usual labs) His most recent PSA has got me all panicked. I am in shock mode right now. My dad's PSA has jumped 23 times in 3 months only. I seek your experiences. Do you think it is remotely possible that this is lab error or poor lab test kit? According to Memorial Sloan Kettering nomogram, my dad had a 97% of recurrence free 2 years after surgery. This most recent PSA defies all that hope. It shatters all that hope I had slowly built after getting the diagnosis. Any thoughts? Depressed physician.
Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: yes, I've already asked him to do a re-test.

Whole prostate Biopsy was negative for perilymphatic invasion, which means microscopically, lymphatics were not infiltrated (most common route of metastasis). Now if a cancer cell fell off from the EPE into the pelvic bed (during trans-rectal biopsy or actual surgery), God knows...

Posts.Content: hopefully, this can help others in the same situation as I am. http://clinical.opko.com/hs-fs/hub/3.../Total_PSA.pdf

Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: Pratoman, thanks for your reply. Did you look into the type of kits these labs were using? Was your falsely elevated PSA on a certain kit? My dad's undetectable PSAs were on Roche Cobas kit which is commonly used in North America. I am not aware of the kit they are using in Middle East. I am trying to find the information on the kit they used in Middle east. It was certainly not ultra-sensitive. Thanks for your understanding.
